text: The Civil Rights Act of 1957, Pub.L. 85â€“315, 71 Stat. 634, enacted September 9, 1957, was a law in the United States. The act did not create new rights. It was primarily a voting rights bill. It was the first civil rights law made by the United States Congress since Reconstruction following the American Civil War. This act stated that all Americans had the right to vote, even African Americans. Category:1957 in the United States Category:United States federal legislation Category:1950s in law
title: Civil Rights Act of 1957
